answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Kevin,
I can't speak for city and town jobs, but nearly every private sector job I've applied for has asked some form of this question to prospective applicants. I had always assumed the public sector operated the same way. Some state and federal agencies go several steps further and initiate background checks, so asking an applicant if he's been convicted of a non-traffic related crime seems to be a pretty mainstream practice. I'm not aware of any legal framework that prohibits this question from being asked by public employers. 
Here is an excellent article I was able to find on an applicants rights concerning arrests and convictions when applying for jobs:
http://www.privacyrights.org/ar/rosencrim.htm
You might also want to contact someone at the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to ask if there are any differences in this area when it comes to public versus private sector jobs. I would imagine that if there are differences it would be that public sector employers are expected to be even more diligent in asking about any prior criminal history than private sector employers. However, it's worth following up with them:
http://www.eeoc.gov/
Hope this is helpful.
Derek Johnson

answers.author: Dele Smith
answers.text:
There is an ongoing "re-entry" movement around the country to more effectively reintegrate ex-offenders into their communities, which means opening up more employment opportunities (among other things). In fact, Minnesota adopted a "Ban the Box" law last year seeking to remove the question about criminal history from job applications until an applicant is selected for an interview (at which point the employer may determine if the offense disqualifies the applicant from the job). In this way, they hope to reduce the stigma faced by ex-offenders. I'm attaching a document summarizing Minnesota's "Ban the Box" legislation.

answers.text:
Additionally, I had the pleasure of participating in America's Leaders of Change last year (a leadership program sponsored by National Urban Fellows and Wal-Mart). One of our projects was to advocate for reentry for ex-offenders. We sent a call to action to the governors of all 50 states and Puerto Rico explaining the public safety, economic, educational, and public health benefits of fully reintegrating ex-offenders into the community. A sample is attached FYI.
